Fig. 1 The particle size distribution curves of all the five catalysts (a). SEM images of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs (b and c). The combined elemental mapping image of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs (c1) and elemental mapping images of Cu (c2), Si (c3), O (c4), Zn (c5), Sn (c6), P (c7), and EDS spectra of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs (d). Fig. 2 TEM image (a) and HRTEM image (b) of the CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs catalyst. Fig. 3 XRD patterns (a), the enlarged view in the 2θ angle range of 34-40° of the catalysts (b), and H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts (c). Fig. 4 XPS spectra of (a) survey spectra, (b) Cu 2p, (c) Zn 2p, and (d) O 1 s. Fig. 5 Catalytic properties of all the catalysts: (a) M2 selectivity, (b) catalytic activity, (c) Si conversion, (d) M2 yield, and (e) Arrhenius plots for the Rochow-Müller reaction on the different catalysts. Fig. 6 Stability tests of the CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs and commercial catalysts at 295 ℃ for 96 h: (a) M2 selectivity, (b) catalytic activity, (c) Si conversion, and (d) M2 yield. Fig. 7 XRD patterns of the catalysts after exposure to MeCl gas flow (25 mL·min-1) at 325 °C for 2 h (a) and 24 h (b). The enlarged views of the typical characteristic peaks are attributed to CuCl (a1 and b1), Cu2O (a2 and b2), and Cu (a3 and b3). Fig. 8 The digital images of the catalysts after exposure to MeCl for 0 h, 2 h, and 24 h: CuO/qs (a1, a2, and a3), CuO-ZnO/qs (b1, b2, and b3), CuO-ZnO-P/qs (c1, c2, and c3), CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs (d1, d2, and d3), and CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs (e1, e2, and e3). Fig. 9 TG curves of the fresh catalysts (a) and the catalysts after exposure to MeCl gas flow at 325 °C for 2 h (b). Fig. 10 XRD patterns of the catalysts with Si powder after exposure to MeCl for 24 h at 295 °C. The enlarged view of the typical characteristic peaks is attributed to CuCl (a1), Cu (a2), and Cu3Si (a3). Fig. 11 XRD patterns of CuO/qs (a) and CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs (b) with Si powder after exposure to MeCl at 325 °C for different periods. Institute of Industrial Chemistry and Energy Technology Shenyang University of Chemical Technology Shenyang 110142 China Graphical abstract The structural evolution of CuO in the Rochow-Müller reaction is deciphered. CuO is first transformed to Cu2O, then to Cu, and further reacted with MeCl to form CuCl. Adding ZnO, Sn, and P promoters to CuO accelerates this phase transformation directly from CuO to Cu, then to CuCl, resulting in the formation of a more active Cu3Si phase and improved catalytic properties. Promoters such as ZnO, Sn, and P are widely used in Cu-based catalysts for the Rochow-Müller reaction, which dominates the manufacture of organosilane monomers in the chemical industry. However, the effect of these promoters on the Cu-based catalyst structure is still unclear. In this work, we prepared a series of quartz sand (qs) supported CuO catalysts modified with ZnO, Sn, and P promoters through simple ball milling followed by calcination in air. We found that introducing these promoters can enhance the MeCl adsorption on the CuO surface, accelerating the transformation of CuO to Cu2O, then to Cu, further to CuCl, and finally to the active Cu3Si phase, leading to the improved catalytic properties with a higher dimethyldichlorosilane selectivity and Si conversion compared to the pure CuO catalyst. This work first deciphers the structural evolution of the CuO catalyst with and without ZnO, Sn, and P promoters during the Rochow-Müller reaction, which would help understand the reaction mechanism and design more efficient catalysts. Keywords Rochow-Müller reaction CuO catalyst Promoters Catalyst structural evolution Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Rochow-Müller reaction, discovered by E.G. Rochow [1] in the United States and R. Müller [2] in Germany in the 1950s, respectively, is the direct reaction of gaseous methyl chloride (CH3Cl, MeCl) with metallurgical-grade silicon (Si) using a Cu-based catalyst [3–5] to selectively produce dimethyldichlorosilane ((CH3)2SiCl2, M2) (see Scheme Fig. S1). The latter is one of the most essential silicone monomers for synthesizing silicone materials [6–8]. This heterogeneous reaction involves gas (MeCl)-solid (Si)-solid (Cu-based catalyst) phases, in which MeCl can react with Si and Cu-based catalysts, accompanied by the solid (Si)-solid (Cu-based catalyst) reaction. As we know, the structure and valence states of most conventional heterogeneous catalysts are usually maintained after the reactions. However, in the Rochow-Müller reaction, the complicated gas–solid-solid reaction leads to a dramatic structural change of Cu-based catalysts, which still has been a “black box” for many years. Therefore, revealing the structural evolution of the Cu-based catalyst during the Rochow-Müller reaction process may be the first step to understanding the reaction mechanism. It has been reported that many Cu-based catalysts, including metallic Cu [9], Cu2O [10], CuO [11,12], CuCl [13], Cu x ZnO y [14], and ternary Cu-CuO-Cu2O composites [15], are effective for the Rochow-Müller reaction. On the other hand, various promoters (e.g., Al [16], Ca [17], Ag [18], In [19], Zn [20,21], Sn [22,23], and P [24]) are found to enhance the catalytic properties of these Cu-based catalysts. For example, Lewis et al. [25] reported that adding Zn and P into CuCl could facilitate the formation of the active Cu3Si phase. Sun et al. [26] found that Zn, Sn, and Al promoters led to higher chlorine reactivity than surface methyl reactivity. Gasper-Galvin et al. [27] noted that Sn, Zn, and Al co-promoters synergistically introduced into Cu catalysts increased the reaction rate and selectivity of M2 by lowering the melting points and surface tensions of the catalyst/promoter alloys. Actually, adding co-promoters of Zn, Sn, and P to Cu-based catalysts is a standard industrial practice to promote M2 selectivity and Si conversion [28]. Our group also developed a series of ZnO-P-Sn multiple promoters that modified the CuO catalysts supported on MO x (MO x = ZrO2 [29], CeO2 [30], and SiO2 [31]) and found that the composition of Cu-based catalysts transformed to metallic Cu and Cu3Si after the reaction. We recently discovered that the Cu2O-based catalysts were first transformed to CuCl and Cu and then to Cu3Si in the Rochow-Müller reaction [32]. However, the detailed transformation process of the CuO-based catalysts from CuO to active Cu3Si phase is still unknown. Following our previous method, this work synthesized a series of CuO catalysts modified with ZnO, Sn, and P promoters but using quartz sand (qs) as the support. The latter is chemically inert during the reaction and could be used as a standard reference in composition identification. As expected, these promoters introduced into the CuO catalysts significantly boost the M2 selectivity and Si conversion. More importantly, we found that CuO without promoter first transformed to Cu2O, then to Cu, further reacting with MeCl to CuCl. The reaction between CuCl and Si generates Cu3Si, which in turn reacts with CuCl or/and MeCl to regenerate Cu, forming a cyclic phase transformation. In contrast, introducing promoters enhances the MeCl adsorption on the CuO surface and accelerates the direct phase transformation of CuO to Cu, then to CuCl, and further to Cu3Si. This work sheds new light on the roles of ZnO, Sn, and P promoters in the Rochow-Müller reaction catalyzed by Cu-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials All analytical-grade chemicals were used without further purification. Cupric carbonate basic (Cu2(OH)2CO3), tin powder (Sn), and zinc oxalate dihydrate (ZnC2O4·2H2O) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., China. Copperphosphorous alloy (CuP, 8 wt% of P) was purchased from Changsha Tianjiu Metal Materials Co., Ltd., China. Quartz sand (qs, SiO2) was purchased from Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., China. Si powder (20–50 mesh) was supplied by Zhejiang Hoshine Silicon Industry Co., Ltd., China. Analytical pure copper chloride (CuCl) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., China. Bulk Cu powder was purchased from Beijing GRIPM Advanced Materials Research Institute Co. Ltd., China. Methyl chloride (CH3Cl) was purchased from Zhejiang Guoya Chemical Industries Co., Ltd., China. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts Table 1 lists the amount of raw materials required to prepare the catalysts. The catalysts were prepared through simple ball milling followed by calcination in air. Taking CuO-ZnO/qs as one example, 55.28 g of Cu2(OH)2CO3, 9.3 g of ZnC2O4·2H2O, and 40 g of SiO2 were mixed and added to the ball-stirring mill (LM-2, Wuxi Xinbiao Powder Machinery Manufacturing Co., Ltd, China). The ratio of ZrO2 balls (5 mm in diameter) to the raw material mixture was 20:1. After ball milling, the active components and qs were evenly mixed, leading to a better dispersion of active components. After ball milling for 0.5 h, the mixture was calcined in air for 1 h at 400 °C. During the calcination process, qs still existed in the form of SiO2, while Cu2(OH)2CO3 and ZnC2O4·2H2O gradually decomposed into CuO and ZnO, respectively. These active CuO and ZnO components may accumulate on the surface of qs under thermal treatment. The obtained catalyst is marked as CuO-ZnO/qs. Other catalysts were synthesized by the same method and expressed as CuO/qs, CuO-ZnO-P/qs, CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs, and CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs. The contents of CuO, SiO2, ZnO, CuP8, and Sn in the CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs raw materials mixture were 47.50, 47.57, 4.80, 0.10, and 0.03 wt%, respectively. Unsupported CuO-ZnO-Sn-P was also prepared using the same method but without adding qs. In addition, the commercial ternary copper catalyst was supplied by Gripm Advanced Materials Co., Ltd. 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was carried out on a PANalytica X′Pert PRO MPD using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA, and the XRD patterns were collected in a 2θ range of 5-90°. The particle size distribution was determined by a laser particle size analyzer on a BT-9300Z with deionized water as the dispersant. The specific surface area of the catalysts was determined using the N2 adsorption method by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) theory in the relative pressure (p/p0 ) range of 0.05–0.30. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained on a JEM-6700F equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected on a JEM-2010 operated at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a VG ESCALAB 250 spectrometer (Thermo Electron, London, U.K.) equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source (hv = 1486.6 eV), and the binding energies (BE) were calibrated using the adventitious C 1 s peak (284.6 eV) as a standard. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was performed with a TG-DTA 6300 Seiko Instrument (Japan) connected to a multichannel acquisition system. Approximately 5 mg of catalyst was placed in a ceramic pan with a volume of 1 mL. TG curves were obtained under a dynamic atmosphere of nitrogen (flow rate of 100 mL·min-1) at the heating rate of 10 °C·min-1 from 30 °C to 800 °C. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis was performed using a Quantachrome automated chemisorption analyzer (Chem BET pulsar TPR/TPD). For each measurement, 0.05 g of catalyst was loaded into a quartz U-tube. Before the measurement, the catalyst was heated from room temperature to 150 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min-1 and kept in a stream of He for 1 h. After cooling to 50 °C, the gas was switched to 10 vol% H2/Ar, and then the catalyst was heated to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min-1 under this atmosphere (30 mL·min-1). During the tests, the H2 consumption was monitored as a TCD signal by the chemisorption analyzer. The ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) absorption spectra were measured on a Shimadzu UV-3600i Plus spectrophotometer (Japan). 2.4 Catalytic measurement The catalysts were evaluated using a fixed-bed flow reactor. 10.0 g of Si powder and 0.5 g of catalyst were thoroughly ground in an agate mortar for 8 min to form a “contact mass”. This mixture was then loaded into the reactor. The upper part of the catalyst bed was also filled with quartz sand to ensure proper heat transfer and stable gas flow. The reactor was purged with pure N2 for 0.5 h and then heated to 325 °C at a flow rate of 25 mL·min-1 of N2 gas for 1 h. Subsequently, N2 was turned off, and 25 mL·min-1 of CH3Cl gas was introduced into the reactor to react with the Si powder at 325 ℃. After reacting for a certain time, the gaseous products were condensed to the liquid state with a circulator bath controlled at −5 °C by a programmable thermal circulator (GDH series, Ningbo Xinzhi Biological Technology Co., LTD). The composition of the products was analyzed using gas chromatography (Agilent Technologies GC-7890A with TCD detector). The products mainly included methyltrichlorosilane (CH3SiCl3, M1), dimethyldichlorosilane ((CH3)2SiCl2, M2), trimethylchlorosilane ((CH3)3SiCl, M3), methyldichlorosilane (CH3SiHCl2, M1H), dimethylchlorosilane ((CH3)2SiHCl, M2H), Low boiling compounds (LBCs), and high boiling compounds (HBCs). The M2 selectivity (SM2), M2 yield (YM2), Si conversion (CSi), and catalytic activity are defined as follows: (1) S M 2 ( % ) = m M 2 m M 1 + m M 2 + m M 3 + m M 1 H + m M 2 H + m L B C s + m H B C s (2) C S i ( % ) = m 0 - m 1 m S i , b e f o r e × 100 % (3) Y M 2 ( % ) = S M 2 C S i 100 (4) A c t i v i t y ( g M 2 m o l C u - 1 h - 1 ) = m M 2 M C u O m C u O t Here, m in equation (1) is the mass of each product, g; m0 and m1 in equation (2) represent the total mass of the reaction tube containing solid mixtures (Si powder, catalyst, and quartz sand) before and after the reaction, respectively, g. mM2 in equation (4) is the mass of M2, g; mCuO is the mass of CuO in the catalyst, g; t is the reaction time, h; MCuO = 79.55 g·mol-1. The activation energy and reaction rate of the Rochow-Müller reaction on the catalysts were determined at a CH3Cl gas flow rate of 25 mL·min-1 in the temperature range of 295–325 ℃ (CSi < 25%). The activation energy is calculated from the Arrhenius equation, and the reaction rate in unit of molSi g-1 cat h-1 is determined by the following equation: (5) r = m Si, before × C Si M Si × 1 m CuO × t = m Si, before C Si M Si m CuO t In Eq. (5), MSi = 28.09 g·mol-1. 2.5 MeCl chemisorption measurement The MeCl chemisorption was performed using the same fixed-bed reactor mentioned in the catalytic performance tests. Specifically, 0.5 g of the catalyst or a mixture of the catalyst and Si powder (20–50 mesh) was loaded into the reactor. The reactor system was purged with N2 for 0.5 h, then heated to desired temperatures. Subsequently, N2 was turned off, and MeCl gas at a flow rate of 25 mL·min-1 was introduced into the reactor to treat the catalyst at the desired temperatures. During this chemisorption process, the Cu-based catalyst may react with MeCl, leading to the catalyst phase transformation. After MeCl chemisorption at different conditions, the catalysts were taken out from the reactor and immediately analyzed by XRD. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 Particle size distribution, SEM, and TEM observations Fig. 1 shows the particle size distribution curves and morphology of the catalysts. All the five catalysts show similar particle size distribution profiles (Fig. 1a), and they have a relatively narrow distribution of particle size with a smaller D50 (1.7 ± 0.1 μm) and D90 (3.0 ± 0.5 μm), as shown in Table 2 . Fig. 1b-c presents the SEM images of the CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs catalyst. Overall, CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs exhibits an irregular spherical morphology (Fig. 1b). The enlarged SEM image (Fig. 1c) shows that the irregular spherical morphology with a particle size of ca. 2 μm is composed of agglomerated nanoparticles. The formation of this irregular spherical morphology may be related to the ball milling process, during which the large particles are broken into fine ones. Subsequently, fine particles agglomerate again to form irregular spherical morphology due to the effect of the surface tension [33]. The measured elemental mapping images (Fig. 1c1-c7) show the uniform distribution of the Cu (Fig. 1c2), Si (Fig. 1c3), O (Fig. 1c4), Zn (Fig. 1c5), Sn (Fig. 1c6), and P (Fig. 1c7) elements in CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs, suggesting that the promoter species are successfully introduced into CuO/qs by the ball milling. The EDS spectrum in Fig. 1d reveals the composition of the elements in CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs. Obviously, the mass ratio of Cu to Si obtained by EDS is nearly 4:1, much larger than their initial precursor ratio (1:1), suggesting that the active CuO tends to be enriched on the surface of SiO2. CuO/qs (Fig. S2), CuO-ZnO/qs (Fig. S3), CuO-ZnO-P/qs (Fig. S4), and CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs (Fig. S5) show similar morphology and Cu surface enrichment. Fig. 2 shows the TEM and HRTEM images of the CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs catalyst. CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs consists of aggregated nanoparticles (Fig. 2a) and is well crystallized (Fig. 2b). The measured inter-planar distance is about 0.232 nm, which corresponds to the (111) plane of CuO [34]. However, no apparent inter-planar distance corresponding to ZnO, Sn, and P is observed due to their low content and high dispersion. 3.1.2 XRD and H2-TPR analysis Fig. 3 a presents the XRD patterns of the catalysts. For CuO/qs, the diffraction peaks at 32.6°, 35.6°, 38.8°, and 48.8° are assigned to the (110), (11–1), (111), and (20–2) crystal planes of monoclinic CuO (PDF#48–1548), respectively, while the diffraction peaks at 20.9°, 26.6°, 42.5°, and 50.1° are indexed to SiO2 (PDF#99–0088). The diffraction peaks of CuO-ZnO/qs, CuO-ZnO-P/qs, CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs, and CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs are similar to those of CuO/qs. Except for the diffraction peaks of CuO and SiO2, no other peaks are observed in these catalysts due to the low concentration (3.6% Zn, 0.1% Sn, and 0.17% P obtained from EDS) and high dispersion of ZnO, Sn, and P on CuO/qs, agreeing with the HRTEM results. As shown in Fig. 3b, there is no shift of the angle values for CuO/qs, indicating that the promoter element does not enter the unit cell of CuO. The average crystallite sizes of CuO within these catalysts calculated using the Debye-Scherrer formula are listed in Table 2. The average crystallite sizes of CuO in all the catalysts are between 22.3 and 24.4 nm. Since all the catalysts are based on qs support, their specific surface areas are similar and relatively low (10.1–13.4 m2/g). All these observations confirm that introducing a promoter does not cause significant structural changes in the catalysts. The H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 3c. All catalysts exhibit a major reduction peak at around 380 °C, which is relevant to the reduction of CuO. Compared with CuO/qs, the consumption of H2 in the promoter-modified CuO/qs catalyst becomes higher (Table 2), suggesting that introducing ZnO, Sn, and P promoters enhances reducibility of CuO. As ZnO cannot be reduced at this temperature range, the increased hydrogen consumption may be related to the reduction of ZnO-promoted CuO. Additionally, it should be noted that the reduction peaks of CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs and CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs are slightly split, which may be due to the Cu–O bond strength difference in different CuO species (e.g., CuO located near Sn or CuO isolated from Sn). 3.1.3 XPS analysis The chemical compositions and oxidation states of the catalysts were characterized by XPS, as shown in Fig. 4 . The survey scan reveals the presence of elements like Cu, Zn, Si, O, and polluted C from the atmosphere (Fig. 4a). Fig. 4b displays the high-resolution XPS spectra of Cu 2p. Two spin–orbit doublets located at 934.1 and 954.2 eV correspond to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 in CuO/qs, respectively, together with the appearance of two satellite peaks (denoted as sat.), demonstrating the existence of Cu2+ and characteristic of CuO [35–37]. After adding ZnO and P, the Cu 2p peak slightly shifts toward lower binding energy, which indicates the electron transfer from ZnO or P to CuO. On the contrary, the Cu 2p peaks in CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs and CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs gradually shift to higher binding energies after introducing SnO2. These binding energy shifts reflect a modification of the electron density on the promoter and CuO species due to the interactive coupling between the CuO and promoter. As shown in Fig. 4c, the Zn XPS spectrum of CuO-ZnO/qs shows two peaks at 1022.4 eV and 1045.4 eV, which corresponds to the electronic states of Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 with a binding energy difference of 23.0 eV, characteristic of Zn2+ [38–40]. After adding Sn or P, the Zn 2p peak shifts relative to the Zn 2p XPS peak of CuO-ZnO/qs, suggesting that interactions exist among the promoters. The O 1 s spectra shown in Fig. 4d display two main peaks, and the one located at 532.18 ± 1.3 eV is assigned to surface adsorbed oxygen species (denoted as Oads), while the other peak centered at ca. 529.78 eV is attributed to lattice oxygen (denoted as Olatt) [41–43]. As shown in Table 2, the atomic ratio of surface adsorbed oxygen to lattice oxygen (Oads/Olatt) follows the order: CuO/qs (1.11) < CuO-ZnO/qs (1.25) < CuO-ZnO-P/qs (1.33) < CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs (1.67) < CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs (2.00), indicating that the introduction of the promoter increases the Oads/Olatt ratio. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the catalysts Fig. 5 shows the catalytic performance of the catalysts in the Rochow-Müller reaction at 325 °C for 48 h. Fig. 5a shows the M2 selectivity as a function of time on stream. For all the catalysts, the M2 selectivity shows a typical “volcano” type curve, which firstly increases rapidly until it reaches its maximum at 8 h and then decreases slowly. As displayed, CuO/qs gives a poor M2 selectivity throughout the entire period. However, a significant increase in M2 selectivity is observed after introducing the promoters. Fig. 5b shows corresponding specific activities that are normalized to their Cu content. The activities of the catalysts follow a similar trend to the M2 selectivity. Compared with CuO/qs, the catalysts containing promoters show increased activity, especially for CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs. As displayed in Fig. 5c and d, CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs achieves a Si conversion of up to 44.1% and M2 yield of 33.6%, much higher than those of other catalysts, which should be mainly due to the synergistic effects between CuO and ZnO-Sn-P promoters. Additionally, the catalytic performance of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P as a reference sample was also evaluated, and the results are shown in Fig. S6. The M2 selectivity, activity, and Si conversion rate of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P are much lower than those of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs. And even doubling the amount of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P, the Si conversion only increases to 32.9%, but still lower than that of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs (44.1%). This suggests that introducing the qs support may lead to better dispersion of active species, thereby improving the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Fig. 5e shows the apparent activation energy (Ea ) of the Rochow-Müller reaction over all the catalysts obtained from the calculated slopes of the fitted lines. The Ea value decreases in the order of CuO/qs (186.7 kJ·mol-1) > CuO-ZnO/qs (115.9 kJ·mol-1) > CuO-ZnO-P/qs (91.6 kJ·mol-1) > CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs (35.1 kJ·mol-1) > CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs (31.9 kJ·mol-1), agreeing with the catalytic activity trend. Adding Zn, Sn, and P promoters significantly reduces the Ea value, especially for CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs, suggesting that the synergistic effects of the multiple promoters greatly lower the reaction activation barrier. In addition, it should also be noted that the Ea value of CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs is similar to CuO-ZnO-Sn-P but much smaller than that of CuO-ZnO/qs and CuO-ZnO-P/qs, suggesting that Sn has a more significant impact on promoting the kinetics of the Rochow-Müller reaction. The catalytic stability of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs and commercial ternary copper catalyst run at 295 °C for 96 h is shown in Fig. 6 . As displayed in Fig. 6a, in the first 48 h, the M2 selectivity of the CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs catalyst is significantly higher than that of the commercial ternary copper catalyst. The M2 selectivity of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs increases quickly, reaches its maximum at 16 h (89.7%), and remains above 80% for 48 h. In contrast, the commercial ternary copper catalyst reaches the maximum M2 selectivity (88.0%) at 72 h. With the prolonging of the reaction time, the M2 selectivity of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs shows a decreasing trend, even slightly lower than that of the commercial catalyst in the later 48 h. The activity of the two catalysts is also compared in Fig. 6b, which shows a similar trend in the M2 selectivity. The activity of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs is nearly 2 times of the commercial catalyst in the first 48 h. Compared with the commercial catalyst, CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs has a higher Si conversion (Fig. 6c) and M2 yield (Fig. 6d). The above results indicate that the CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs catalyst is promising for industrial application due to its good catalytic performance and stability. 3.3 The structure transformation of the catalyst during the MeCl chemisorption process As evidenced by the XRD results of the waste contact masses (Fig. S7), CuO in all the catalysts is transformed to metallic Cu and Cu3Si. The formation of Cu3Si, which is considered the key active phase, is due to the mutual diffusion of Si and Cu [29–31], which can also be confirmed by SEM results of the waste contact mass (Fig. S8). Therefore, the CuO-based catalyst underwent a phase transformation in the Rochow-Müller reaction. The MeCl chemisorption process was systematically investigated to understand the structural evolution of the catalyst during the reaction. Fig. 7 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts after exposing them to MeCl gas at 325 °C for 2 h and 24 h, respectively. From Fig. 7a, no diffraction peak of the CuO phase is observed in the XRD patterns of all the catalysts, suggesting the complete phase transformation of the CuO phase under MeCl flow at 325 °C for 2 h. In contrast, due to its chemical stability, the quartz sand support retains its original SiO2 phase. For the CuO/qs catalyst, the CuCl phase appears and becomes the primary phase, accompanied by the disappearance of the CuO phase. Additionally, the weak peaks at 29.6°, 36.4°, and 61.4° attributed to Cu2O, and the peaks at 43.3°, 50.4°, and 74.1° attributed to Cu are also observed, respectively. The enlarged XRD patterns in Fig. 7a1-a3 clearly display the peaks of CuCl at 28.5°, Cu2O at 29.6°, and Cu at 43.3° for all the catalysts. The conversion of CuO to CuCl and Cu phases is also observed in other catalysts. However, there is no Cu2O phase observed in CuO/qs catalysts modified by the promoters. This is because introducing the promoters accelerated the phase transformation of CuO; thus, the Cu2O intermediate phase could not be captured during the rapid conversion of CuO to Cu. Although CuCl can be decomposed into Cu at high temperatures, it is difficult to take place under the MeCl atmosphere, as confirmed by the XRD pattern of CuCl after being treated in MeCl gas for 2 h at 325 °C (Fig. S9). Therefore, the intermediate Cu phase is obtained by the gradual reduction of CuO by MeCl other than the decomposition of CuCl. Additionally, the peak intensity of Cu in the promoter-modified CuO/qs is significantly higher than that of CuO/qs, as shown in Fig. 7a3. Table 3 lists the peak intensity ratios of CuCl (or Cu) to SiO2. Obviously, the peak intensity ratio of CuCl (or Cu) to SiO2 in CuO/qs is lower than that of other catalysts, implying the promoters accelerated the phase transformation of CuO under MeCl. When the time of the catalyst exposed to MeCl is extended to 24 h, as shown in Fig. 7b and Fig. 7b1-b3, CuO is completely converted to CuCl in all catalysts. Additionally, compared to MeCl chemisorption for 2 h, the peak intensity ratio of CuCl to SiO2 in all the catalysts becomes significantly stronger after 24 h of the MeCl chemisorption. Based on the above analysis, it is deduced that CuO is first reduced to Cu2O, then to Cu, and finally to CuCl. In the cases of introducing promoters, CuO is preferentially converted to Cu without detecting the Cu2O intermediate and finally to CuCl. However, it cannot be ruled out that partial CuO or Cu2O may react directly with MeCl to generate CuCl. Considering that color differences exist among different Cu-based species, the color changes of the catalysts after exposure to MeCl for 0 h, 2 h, and 24 h were recorded by digital camera, as shown in Fig. 8 , to further confirm the phase transformation of CuO during the MeCl chemisorption process. All the fresh catalysts have a black CuO color (Fig. 8a1-e1). After being exposed to MeCl for 2 h, the catalysts exhibit a red color (Fig. 8a2-e2), indicating the existence of Cu. In contrast, after exposure to MeCl for 24 h, the catalysts exhibit a white color (Fig. 8a3-e3), indicating the formation of CuCl. The color change of the catalyst images after exposure to MeCl for 2 h and 24 h is consistent with the phase composition analysis shown in Fig. 7. These catalysts were further characterized by UV–vis absorption spectra, and the results are shown in Fig. S10. From Fig. S10a, two intense absorption bands are located within the wavelength ranges of 200–370 nm and 370–800 nm in the spectrum of the fresh CuO/qs, which is due to the characteristic color of black CuO. For CuO/qs after exposure to MeCl gas flow for 2 h, black CuO is converted to a mixture of Cu, Cu2O, and CuCl; thus the absorption peak intensity is significantly reduced. The peak at 365, 325 nm, and 567 nm is attributed to CuCl, Cu2O, and Cu, respectively [44,45]. However, the absorption band in the 400–515 nm still exists, which may be due to the presence of residual CuO. After exposing CuO/qs to MeCl gas flow for 24 h, CuO is wholly converted to white CuCl, which does not display any observable optical absorption above 400 nm. The UV–vis spectra of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs after exposure to MeCl gas flow for different periods (Fig. S10b) show similar features to those seen in Fig. S10a. In contrast, CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs after being treated in MeCl gas for 2 h at 325 °C shows the characteristic peaks of white CuCl and red Cu, but no presence of Cu2O, which is in good agreement with the color change obtained in Fig. 8. Considering that CuCl is prone to sublimation under high-temperature conditions, the catalysts after adsorption of MeCl were further characterized by the TG technique to determine the amount of adsorbed MeCl. From Fig. 9 a, no weight loss is detected for the fresh CuO-based catalyst in the N2 atmosphere over the whole temperature range from 100 to 800 °C. However, CuCl displays a large weight loss. More specifically, the thermal evolution of CuCl in the N2 atmosphere occurs in two steps. The first step (at ca. 200–400 °C) is the desorption of water or other species adsorbed on the CuCl surface. The second step (at ca. 400–700 °C) is the evaporation of CuCl. Fig. 9b shows the TG results of the catalysts after exposure to MeCl gas flow at 325 °C for 2 h. As shown in Fig. 9b, all the catalysts after adsorption of MeCl exhibit a similar weight-losing behavior to that of CuCl, further confirming that CuO in the catalyst after adsorption of MeCl at 325 °C for 2 h converts into CuCl. Therefore, the weight loss for the catalyst after the adsorption of MeCl in Fig. 9b largely depends on the amount of CuCl generated. From Fig. 9b, the total weight loss reaches 29.7% up to 700 °C for the CuO/qs catalyst, which is significantly lower than the weight loss of 37.3% of CuO-ZnO/qs. After further introducing Sn, P, or Sn-P into CuO-ZnO/qs, the weight loss becomes greater. This trend indicates that introducing promoters increases the amount of MeCl adsorbed by the catalyst under the same chemisorption conditions and generates more CuCl. Furthermore, the contents of Cu and CuCl in the catalysts after exposure to MeCl gas flow at 325 °C for 2 h were calculated according to the TG result. It should be noted that the ratio of Cu2O to Cu in CuO/qs is assumed to be 3:2 based on XRD analysis in Fig. 7a. As shown in Table 3, the content of Cu and CuCl in CuO/qs is 0.114 g and 0.297 g, respectively, lower than those in the promoter-modified CuO/qs. These results indicate that introducing promoters generates more MeCl adsorption sites on CuO and forms more CuCl and Cu, agreeing with the results obtained in Fig. 7a. The phase composition of the catalysts after being exposed to the MeCl gas in the presence of Si powder at 295 °C for 24 h was investigated by XRD, and the results are shown in Fig. 10. CuO/qs, CuO-ZnO/qs, and CuO-ZnO-P/qs all show the peaks of CuCl. It should be noted that the main XRD peaks of Si and CuCl are very close except for the weak peak at 33.0° for the CuCl (200) plane. As shown in the enlarged XRD patterns in Fig. 10a1-a3, no Cu3Si or Cu peak is observed in CuO/qs, CuO-ZnO/qs, and CuO-ZnO-P/qs during the MeCl chemisorption process, suggesting that Si may not react with MeCl under this condition. In contrast, both CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs and CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs exhibit different phase compositions. The weak peak of CuCl that differs from Si at 33.1° is wholly disappeared, accompanied by the appearance of a strong diffraction peak of Cu at 43.3° (Fig. 10 a2) and the peak attributed to Cu3Si (Fig. 10 a3), suggesting that adding ZnO-Sn or ZnO-Sn-P can form the active Cu3Si phase at 295 °C. Next, the phase evolution of the catalyst with time in the presence of Si powder at 325 °C was studied. Fig. 11 shows the XRD patterns of CuO/qs and CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs with Si powder exposed to MeCl gas at 325 °C for different times (0–48 h). As shown in Fig. 11a, the peaks attributed to the CuO phase completely disappear at 0.5 h. The enlarged view of the XRD patterns in Fig. 11a1-a5 clearly shows the phase change of various species. The weak peaks of the Cu2O and CuCl phases are observed after 0.5 h exposure to MeCl in the CuO/qs catalyst. With the extension of the exposure time, the peak at 29.6° attributed to Cu2O (Fig. 11a2) and the peak at 33.1° attributed to CuCl (Fig. 11a3) become weak gradually and almost disappear at 8 h. Conversely, the peak at 43.3° attributed to the Cu phase appears, and its intensity gradually increases from 8 to 48 h. Simultaneously, the Cu3Si phase appears at 8 h, reaches its maximum value in intensity, and then gradually weakens (Fig. 11a5) and becomes very weak at 48 h (Fig. S11a). During the whole MeCl chemisorption process, Cu3Si is first generated and then consumed. In contrast, CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs exhibits a different phase transformation behavior (Fig. 11b and Fig. 11b1-b5). As shown in Fig. 11b2, no diffraction peak of Cu2O is observed in the whole MeCl chemisorption process. The diffraction peaks of Cu and Cu3Si in CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs appear earlier at 0.5 and 1 h, respectively. Simultaneously, the appearance of the Cu3Si phase is accompanied by the disappearance of the CuCl phase, which is also observed in our previous work [32]. With the increase of the MeCl adsorption time, the peak intensity of Cu3Si gradually weakens (Fig. 11b5 and Fig. S11b), while the Cu diffraction peak increases in intensity (Fig. 11b4). The final phase is consistent with that of the waste contact masses, as shown in Fig. S7, suggesting that Si reacts with the MeCl and CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs catalyst during this process. A similar phase change of the CuO occurs in the CuO-ZnO/qs (Fig. S12a), CuO-ZnO-P/qs (Fig. S12b), and CuO-ZnO-Sn/qs (Fig. S12c) catalysts. The above analysis for the MeCl adsorption process suggests that adding the promoter into CuO accelerates the phase transformation of CuO in the presence of Si powder and promotes the formation of the active Cu3Si phase. The final Cu phase may partly originate from the consumption of the Cu3Si phase, which releases Cu if there is no available Si to fill the Si vacancy. In addition, the Cu phase may also come from the reaction of Cu3Si with CuCl, as Souha et al reported [46]. At last, it is observed that the diffraction peak of Si powder overlapping with that of CuCl at 28.4° gradually weakened with the extension of the exposure time, accompanied by the weakening of the Cu3Si peak, suggesting that Si powder and CuCl are constantly being consumed. However, due to the overlap of the main XRD peaks of Si powder and CuCl, it is difficult to identify the presence of CuCl from Fig. 11 in the final phase. As evidenced by Fig. 7 and Fig. S13, the metallic Cu phase can be transformed to CuCl under MeCl at 325 °C. Therefore, the CuCl phase probably exists in the final phase. From the measured catalytic performances and variation of the XRD peak intensity ratios of Cu3Si to SiO2 versus MeCl chemisorption time as shown in Fig. S14, it is found that the selectivity of M2 is directly proportional to the generation of Cu3Si. Additionally, the selectivity of M2 decreases with the consumption of Cu3Si (Fig. S14a). However, as shown in Fig. S14b, the Si conversion ratio is correlated with the reaction time, not Cu3Si. Therefore, the generated Cu3Si, which is supposed to be the main active phase, is crucial for the selective generation of M2 but has little relation to the Si conversion ratio in the Rochow-Müller reaction. Table 4 lists the phase compositions of the catalysts with Si powder after exposure to MeCl at 325 °C for different reaction times. At 0.5 h, the CuCl and Cu2O phases appear in CuO/qs, while the CuCl and Cu phases appear in CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs. When the exposure time is extended to 1 h, there is no change in phase composition for CuO/qs. However, the Cu3Si phase appears at 1 h in the case of CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs, along with the disappearance of CuCl, suggesting that adding the promoter can accelerate the transformation of CuO to CuCl and then to the active Cu3Si phase. 3.4 Proposed reaction mechanism Based on the above MeCl chemisorption results and previous studies [29–31], a comprehensive Rochow-Müller reaction mechanism over CuO-based catalysts is proposed and illustrated in Fig. 12 . When MeCl is introduced into the contact mass, the MeCl molecules react with the lattice oxygen of CuO to generate Cu2O. Then, Cu2O continues to react with MeCl to produce Cu and CuCl. Finally, Cu2O is completely converted into CuCl with the extension of reaction time. However, introducing the ZnO, Sn, and P promoters into CuO/qs catalyst directly converts CuO into CuCl and Cu phase without the Cu2O intermediate phase. In the presence of Si powder, CuCl can be activated and diffused to the surface of the Si matrix to attack the Si-Si bonds as the reaction progresses, leading to the formation of the active Cu3Si phase. Once the Cu3Si phase is formed, Si− as a nucleophile in Cu3Si adsorbs the electrophilic CH3 +, and the Cu+ site adsorbs Cl−. Subsequently, the nucleophilic Cl− diffuses and combines with Si to form M2 via an exothermic process. As the reaction progresses, Si and CuCl diffuse to each other side, leading to gradual etching of the Si surface. When the reaction reaches a particular stage, the metallic Cu species is re-formed due to the consumption of the active Cu3Si phase. Metallic Cu species can also react with MeCl and continue to generate CuCl, as evidenced by the phase transformation process of the CuO-based catalyst without Si powder during the MeCl chemisorption process (in Fig. 7 and Fig. S13). In the subsequent catalytic cycle, the reformed CuCl under MeCl can migrate to the Si surface and form active Cu3Si species. Therefore, the waste contact mass should include the unreacted Si, Cu, CuCl, and Cu3Si in the Rochow-Müller reaction. Due to the overlapping diffraction peaks of CuCl and Si powder, the existence of CuCl was ignored in previous studies. For the multiple promoters-modified CuO/qs catalyst, the phase transformation of CuO to the active phases is accelerated during the reaction process, thereby promoting the reaction. 4 Conclusions A series of quartz sand-supported CuO catalysts modified by multiple promoters (ZnO, Sn, and P) are successfully synthesized by a simple ball milling method. Adding the promoters significantly increases the M2 selectivity and Si conversion in the Rochow-Müller reaction, especially for the CuO-ZnO-Sn-P/qs catalyst. TG analysis demonstrates that introducing the promoter increases the adsorption amount of MeCl on CuO catalysts. MeCl chemisorption analysis reveals that CuO undergoes a series of phase transformations under MeCl from CuO to Cu2O and Cu, then to CuCl. Introducing the promoter accelerates the phase transformation of CuO, in which CuO reacts with MeCl to directly generate Cu without generating the Cu2O intermediate phase. The accelerated phase transformation favors the formation of the active Cu3Si phase and lowers the reaction activation barriers, thereby improving the catalytic performance of the catalysts. This work deciphers the structural evolution of the CuO catalyst with and without ZnO, Sn, and P promoters and clarifies the reaction mechanism of the Rochow-Müller reaction. coredata.dc:description: Promoters such as ZnO, Sn, and P are widely used in Cu-based catalysts for the Rochow-Müller reaction, which dominates the manufacture of organosilane monomers in the chemical industry. However, the effect of these promoters on the Cu-based catalyst structure is still unclear. In this work, we prepared a series of quartz sand (qs) supported CuO catalysts modified with ZnO, Sn, and P promoters through simple ball milling followed by calcination in air. We found that introducing these promoters can enhance the MeCl adsorption on the CuO surface, accelerating the transformation of CuO to Cu2O, then to Cu, further to CuCl, and finally to the active Cu3Si phase, leading to the improved catalytic properties with a higher dimethyldichlorosilane selectivity and Si conversion compared to the pure CuO catalyst. This work first deciphers the structural evolution of the CuO catalyst with and without ZnO, Sn, and P promoters during the Rochow-Müller reaction, which would help understand the reaction mechanism and design more efficient catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Structural evolution of the CuO catalyst modified with ZnO, Sn, and P promoters in the Rochow-Müller reaction
